content.value: Joe's big, dumb face is being pulled down from the ceiling by a beefy man in a cherry picker. Even now, at the absolute death of the week and in sweltering conditions, everyone works together to get the stand down, packed and in the van as quickly as possible so they can retire to the hotel in preparation for tomorrow's journey home. The week has left everyone exhausted; it has been intense but hopefully worth it.

When you hear of the amount of effort it takes to make a game, we tend to nod and agree but not really think about it. That's because we only ever hear about it and we've never seen it; those so-called 'behind the scenes' affairs never show us the real story; they are tightly controlled promotional vehicles, stripped of character and feeling.

What is 'behind the scenes'? Is it showing off a 3D wireframe of a character before a texture is applied? A prepared speech from a dev about game mechanics? A layman's explanation of a patented graphics engine? Or is it looking at the people who made the game, their ambitions, fears and hopes?

This is the advantage of a smaller studio which has retained its independence: there is a still a need to make money – arguably moreso than a major established studio – but everyone feels like they're pulling in the same direction, making something they love and care about.

When you look at the people behind the hard work, you look behind the scenes. You get to know them, you see the faces behind the end result; you see how people pull together in rough times; you see what hard work looks like and, at the dying breath of a major event like this, it is written on weary, yet ultimately relieved, faces, that it is of the utmost importance to everyone here that they make the best game they can possibly make.

I can't say I was surprised to see the scale and ambition of their latest, upcoming game, No Man's Sky, as it perfectly fits the spirit in which the company was set up in the first place; in the meeting that starts this story, Sean said something to the team which stuck with me for the remainder of my time with them: 'I don't even care at this stage whether it does well, I just want us to have made a game that we can be proud of'.

As the team work on No Man's Sky, workloads, pressures, obligations, important decisions, have escalated and intensified as they aim to deliver on a huge promise. I know they will do everything in their power to make this happen because, in spite of the pressures, Hello Games truly believe that making games is fun.
